distortions.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
distortions.description: Seeing things in black-and-white categories. If your performance falls short of perfect, you see yourself as a total failure.
examples: I made one mistake, so I'm a complete failure
If I can't do it perfectly, there's no point in trying
Either I'm the best or I'm the worst
distortions.reframe_prompt: Look for shades of gray. Most situations exist on a spectrum, not in extremes.

distortions.name: Overgeneralization
distortions.description: Seeing a single negative event as a never-ending pattern of defeat using words like 'always' or 'never'.
examples: I always mess things up
Nothing ever goes right for me
This always happens to me
distortions.reframe_prompt: Consider specific instances rather than generalizing. One event doesn't define a pattern.

distortions.name: Mental Filtering
distortions.description: Picking out a single negative detail and dwelling on it exclusively, filtering out all positive aspects.
examples: One person criticized my work, so the whole project is bad
I only notice the things that went wrong
I can't stop thinking about that one negative comment
distortions.reframe_prompt: Try to see the full picture. What positive aspects might you be overlooking?

distortions.name: Disqualifying the Positive
distortions.description: Rejecting positive experiences by insisting they 'don't count' for some reason.
examples: They only said that to be nice
That success was just luck
Anyone could have done that
distortions.reframe_prompt: Accept compliments and positive outcomes at face value. You deserve credit for your achievements.

distortions.name: Jumping to Conclusions
distortions.description: Making negative interpretations without actual evidence. This includes mind reading (assuming you know what others think) and fortune telling (predicting things will turn out badly).
examples: They didn't text back, so they must hate me
I know this presentation will be a disaster
She looked at me funny, she must be judging me
distortions.reframe_prompt: Check the evidence. What facts support or contradict your conclusion?

distortions.name: Magnification / Catastrophizing
distortions.description: Exaggerating the importance of things (like your mistakes or someone else's achievements), or minimizing things (your own desirable qualities).
examples: This mistake will ruin my entire career
If I fail this test, my life is over
This is the worst thing that could happen
distortions.reframe_prompt: Put things in perspective. How will this matter in a week, month, or year?

distortions.name: Emotional Reasoning
distortions.description: Assuming that your negative emotions reflect reality: 'I feel it, therefore it must be true.'
examples: I feel stupid, so I must be stupid
I feel guilty, so I must have done something wrong
I feel overwhelmed, so my problems must be impossible to solve
distortions.reframe_prompt: Feelings are not facts. What objective evidence exists separate from how you feel?

distortions.name: Should Statements
distortions.description: Using 'should', 'must', or 'ought' statements to motivate yourself or others, leading to guilt and frustration.
examples: I should be better at this by now
I must not make any mistakes
They should know how I feel
distortions.reframe_prompt: Replace 'should' with 'could' or 'would like to'. Be gentle with yourself and others.

distortions.name: Labeling
distortions.description: Attaching a negative label to yourself or others instead of describing the specific behavior.
examples: I'm such a loser
I'm an idiot
They're a terrible person
distortions.reframe_prompt: Separate the behavior from the person. You made a mistake - that doesn't define who you are.

distortions.name: Personalization
distortions.description: Seeing yourself as the cause of negative external events that you were not primarily responsible for.
examples: It's my fault the team failed
If only I had done something different, this wouldn't have happened
They're upset because of me
distortions.reframe_prompt: Consider all factors that contributed. Most outcomes involve multiple causes beyond your control.
